awd_titl_txt: IUCRC Planning Grant Carnegie Mellon University: Center for Materials Data Science for Reliability and Degradation (MDS-Rely)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project proposes to plan a new site in the Center on Data Science for Materials Reliability and Degradation (MDS-Rely) by garnering industry support and feedback on applying data science-informed research to understand reliability and lifetime of materials, and use this feedback to ensure the Center is responsive to industry needs. Reliability of materials, parts and products are essential for US infrastructure in energy, defense, and national health and welfare. MDS-Rely will recruit potential industry partners interested in conducting research with the Center to apply data science to materials development. The planning grant will then garner feedback from these industry partners on the following objectives of the Center: (1) Enhance reliability testing, (2) Develop degradation models, (3) Apply degradation models, and (4) Develop educational programs. Together these efforts will enhance national interests.


MDS-Rely will harness relationships between industry and academia to make headways in applying data science to applied materials development, design, and reliability. There will be three intellectual thrusts: (1) Soft and biomaterial formulation; (2) Natural language processing for data science of materials; and (3) Data-driven design of catalytic materials and processes. The soft and biomaterial formulation thrust will encompass machine-learning augmented design of experiments and automated science. The natural language processing thrust will focus on leveraging the existing literature more effectively in the area of materials reliability and degradation. Finally, the data-driven design of catalyst materials and processes will combine automated simulation with process systems engineering to discover materials and processes that are robust to degradation. The new site will leverage strengths at the intersections of computing, data science and machine learning with domain expertise in soft and biomaterials as well as catalysis at Carnegie Mellon University.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit We attended the IUCRC bootcamp in the fall of 2023. During this we performed about a dozen interviews with potential industrial members. From these interviews we identified the following potential areas of interest:

  1. Large language models in degradation and reliability
  2. Degradation and reliability of soft material formulations

The PI worked with the MDS-Rely leadership to develop a planning meeting. There were 76 registrants and 17 companies in attendance, including the existing MDS-Rely Industrial Advisory Board. The meeting took place in two parts: the first day took place on April 16, 2024 at the University of Pittsburgh and was the usual annual spring meeting of MDS-Rely. That evening the meeting transitioned to Carnegie Mellon University for a poster session and kick-off dinner. The second day of the meeting was on April 17, 2024 at Carnegie Mellon University. During this meeting we presented potential research projects, and obtained feedback from participants on the relevance of the projects and their interest in them.

The planning meeting was coincided with the annual spring MDS-Rely meeting so that new members would be able to see what the existing MDS-Rely center does, and current members would have an opportunity to meet the potential members and help to recruit them. After the meeting we followed up with all the invited guests with information from the meeting and to keep them engaged in the membership decision-making process. This ultimately led to the preparation of a full proposal for a site-addition to MDS-Rely.

Broader impacts Part of the planning meeting involved a student poster session that included undergraduate senior projects and graduate student projects that were either supported by MDS-Rely or that were part of the proposed projects in this proposal. These students got to interact with the industry members and guests, which helped the students better understand how their work impacts industry. We also had student scribes during the meeting where they had the opportunity to learn about research topics outside their current work.

 


Last Modified: 10/01/2024
Modified by: John R Kitchin
